langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following

div2.head: Actus Primus. Scoena Prima.
div2.stage: Enter the King, Lord Iohn of Lancaster, Earle of Westmerland, with others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: SO shaken as we are, so wan with care,
Find we a time for frighted Peace to pant,
And breath short winded accents of new broils
To be commenced in Strands afar remote:
No more the thirsty entrance of this Soil,
Shall daub her lips with her own children's blood:
No more shall trenching War channel her fields,
Nor bruise her Flowerets with the Armed hooves
Of hostile paces. Those opposed eyes,
Which like the Meteors of a troubled Heaven,
All of one Nature, of one Substance bred,
Did lately meet in the intestine shock,
And furious close of civil Butchery,
Shall now in mutual well-beseeming ranks
March all one way, and be no more opposed
Against Acquaintance, Kindred, and Allies.
The edge of War, like an ill-sheathed knife,
No more shall cut his Master. Therefore Friends,
As far as to the Sepulchre of Christ,
Whose Soldier now under whose blessed Cross
We are impressed and engaged to fight,
Forthwith a power of English shall we levy,
Whose arms were moulded in their Mothers womb,
To chase these Pagans in those holy Fields,
Over whose Acres walked those blessed feet
Which fourteen hundred years ago were nailed
For our advantage on the bitter Cross.
But this our purpose is a twelve-month old,
And bootless it is to tell you we will go:
Therefore we meet not now. Then let me hear
Of you my gentle Cousin Westmerland,
What yesternight our Council did decree,
In forwarding this dear expedience.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: My Liege: This haste was hot in question,
And many limits of the Charge set down
But yesternight: when all athwart there came
A Post from Wales, laden with heavy News;
Whose worst was, That the Noble Mortimer,
Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight
Against the irregular and wild Glendower,
Was by the rude hands of that Welshman taken,
And a thousand of his people butchered:
Upon whose dead corpse there was such misuse,
Such beastly, shameless transformation,
By those Welshwomen done, as may not be
(Without much shame) re-told or spoken of.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It seems then, that the tidings of this broil,
Brake off our business for the Holy land.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: This matched with other like, my gracious Lord,
Far more uneven and unwelcome News
Came from the North, and thus it did report:
On Holy-rood day, the gallant Hotspurre there,
Young Harry Percy, and brave Archibald,
That ever-valiant and approved Scot,
At Holmeden met, where they did spend
A sad and bloody hour:
As by discharge of their Artillery,
And shape of likely-hood the news was told:
For he that brought them, in the very heat
And pride of their contention, did take horse,
Uncertain of the issue any way.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here is a dear and true industrious friend:
Sir Walter Blunt, new lighted from his Horse,
Strained with the variation of each soil,
Betwixt that Holmedon, and this Seat of ours:
And he hath brought us smooth and welcomes news.
The Earl of Dowglas is discomfited,
Ten thousand bold Scots, two and twenty Knights
Balked in their own blood did Sir Walter see
On Holmedons Plains. Of Prisoners, Hotspurre took
Mordake Earl of Fife, and eldest son
To beaten Dowglas, and the Earl of Atholl,
Of Murry, Angus, and Menteith.
And is not this an honourable spoil?
A gallant prize? Ha Cousin, is it not? I'faith it is.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: A Conquest for a Prince to boast of.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yea, there thou makest me sad, & makest me sin,
In envy, that my Lord Northumberland
Should be the Father of so blessed a Son:
A Son, who is the Theme of Honours tongue;
Amongst a Grove, the very straightest Plant,
Who is sweet Fortunes Minion, and her Pride:
Whilst I by looking on the praise of him,
See Riot and Dishonour stain the brow
Of my young Harry. O that it could be proved,
That some Night-tripping-Fairy, had exchanged
In Cradle-clothes, our Children where they lay,
And called mine Percy, his Plantagenet:
Then would I have his Harry, and he mine:
But let him from my thoughts. What think you Cuz
Of this young Percies pride? The Prisoners
Which he in this adventure hath surprised,
To his own use he keeps, and sends me word
I shall have none but Mordake Earl of Fife.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: This is his Uncles teaching. This is Worcester
Malevolent to you in all Aspects:
Which makes him prune himself, and bristle up
The crest of Youth against your Dignity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But I have sent for him to answer this:
And for this cause awhile we must neglect
Our holy purpose to Jerusalem.
Cousin, on Wednesday next, our Council we will hold
At Windsor, and so inform the Lords:
But come yourself with speed to us again,
For more is to be said, and to be done,
Than out of anger can be uttered.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: I will my Liege.

div2.head: Scaena Secunda.
div2.stage: Enter Henry Prince of Wales, Sir Iohn Falstaffe, and Pointz.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Now Hal, what time of day is it Lad?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Thou art so fat-witted with drinking of old
Sack, and unbuttoning thee after Supper, and sleeping
upon Benches in the afternoon, that thou hast forgotten
to demand that truly, which thou wouldest truly know.
What a devil hast thou to do with the time of the day?
unless hours were cups of Sack, and minutes Capons,
and clocks the tongues of Bawds, and dials the signs
of Leaping-houses, and the blessed Sun himself a fair
hot Wench in Flame-coloured Taffeta; I see no reason,
why thou shouldest be so superfluous, to demand the
time of the day.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Indeed you come near me now Hal, for we that
take Purses, go by the Moon and seven Stars, and not
by Phoebus he, that wandering Knight so fair. And I
prithee sweet Wag, when thou art King, as God save
thy Grace, Majesty I should say, for Grace thou wilt
have none.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What, none?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
No, not so much as will serve to be Prologue to
an Egg and Butter.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Well, how then? Come roundly, roundly.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Marry then, sweet Wag, when thou art King,
let not us that are Squires of the Nights body, be called
Thieves of the Days beauty. Let us be Dianaes Foresters, Gentlemen of the Shade, Minions of the Moon;
and let men say, we be men of good Government, being
governed as the Sea is, by our noble and chaste mistress the
Moon, under whose countenance we steal.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Thou sayst well, and it holds well too: for the
fortune of us that are the Moons men, doth ebb and
flow like the Sea, being governed as the Sea is, by the
Moon: as for proof. Now a Purse of Gold most resolutely snatched on Monday night, and most dissolutely
spent on Tuesday Morning; got with swearing, Lay by:
and spent with crying, Bring in: now, in as low an ebb
as the foot of the Ladder, and by and by in as high a flow
as the ridge of the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Thou sayst true Lad: and is not my Hostess of
the Tavern a most sweet Wench?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
As is the honey, my old Lad of the Castle: and is
not a Buff Jerkin a most sweet robe of durance?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
How now? how now mad Wag? What in thy
quips and thy quiddities? What a plague have I to do
with a buff jerkin?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Why, what a pox have I to do with my Hostess of the Tavern?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Well, thou hast called her to a reckoning many a
time and oft.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Did I ever call for thee to pay thy part?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No, I will give thee thy due, thou hast paid all there.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Yea and elsewhere, so far as my Coin would
stretch, and where it would not, I have used my credit.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Yea, and so used it, that were it here apparent,
that thou art Heir apparent. But I prithee sweet Wag,
shall there be Gallows standing in England when thou
art King? and resolution thus fobbed as it is, with the rusty curb of old Father Antic the Law? Do not thou
when thou art a King, hang a Thief.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: No, thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Shall I? O rare! I will be a brave Judge.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Thou judgest false already. I mean, thou shalt
have the hanging of the Thieves, and so become a rare
Hangman.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Well Hal, well: and in some sort it jumps with
my humour, as well as waiting in the Court, I can tell
you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: For obtaining of suites?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Yea, for obtaining of suites, whereof the Hangman hath no lean Wardrobe. I am as Melancholy as a
gib-cat, or a lugged Bear.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Or an old Lion, or a Lovers Lute.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Yea, or the Drone of a Lincolnshire Bagpipe.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
What sayst thou to a Hare, or the Melancholy
of Moore Ditch?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Thou hast the most unsavoury smiles, and art indeed the most comparative rascallest sweet young Prince.
But Hal, I prithee trouble me no more with vanity, I wold
thou and I knew, where a Commodity of good names
were to be bought: an old Lord of the Council rated
me the other day in the street about you sir; but I marked
him not, and yet he talked very wisely, but I regarded
him not, and yet he talked wisely, and in the street too.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Thou didst well: for no man regards it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
O, thou hast damnable iteration, and art indeed
able to corrupt a Saint. Thou hast done much harm unto me Hall, God forgive thee for it. Before I knew thee
Hal, I knew nothing: and now I am (if a man should speak
truly) little better than one of the wicked. I must give over this life, and I will give it over: if I do not, I am a
Villain. I will be damned for never a Kings son in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Where shall we take a purse tomorrow, Iacke?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Where thou wilt Lad, I will make one: and I do
not, call me Villain, and baffle me.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
I see a good amendment of life in thee: From
Praying, to Purse-taking.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Why, Hal, it is my Vocation Hal: It is no sin for a
man to labour in his Vocation.
Pointz. Now shall we know if Gads hill have set a
Watch. O, if men were to be saved by merit, what hole
in Hell were hot enough for him? This is the most omnipotent Villain, that ever cried, Stand, to a true man.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Good morrow Ned.

sp.speaker: Poines.
sp.p:
Good morrow sweet Hal. What says Monsieur Remorse? What says Sir Iohn Sack and Sugar:
Iacke? How agrees the Devil and thee about thy Soul,
that thou soldest him on Good-Friday last, for a Cup of
Medeira, and a cold Capons leg?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn stands to his word, the devil shall have
his bargain, for he was never yet a Breaker of Proverbs:
He will give the devil his due.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p:
Then art thou damned for keeping thy word with
the devil.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Else he had damned for cozening the devil.

sp.speaker: Poy.
sp.p:
But my Lads, my Lads, tomorrow morning, by
four o'clock early at Gads hill, there are Pilgrims going to Canterbury with rich Offerings, and Traders riding to London with fat Purses. I have vizards for you
all; you have horses for yourselves: Gads-hill lies
tonight in Rochester, I have bespoke Supper tomorrow in
Eastcheape; we may do it as secure as sleep: if you will
go, I will stuff your Purses full of Crowns: if you will
not, tarry at home and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hear ye Yedward, if I tarry at home and go not,
I will hang you for going.

sp.speaker: Poy.
sp.p: You will chops.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Hal, wilt thou make one?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Who, I rob? I a Thief? Not I.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
There is neither honesty, manhood, nor good fellowship in thee, nor thou camest not of the blood-royal,
if thou darest not stand for ten shillings.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Well then, once in my days I will be a mad-cap.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, that is well said.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Well, come what will, I will tarry at home.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I will be a Traitor then, when thou art King.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: I care not.

sp.speaker: Poyn.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, I prithee leave the Prince & me alone,
I will lay him down such reasons for this adventure, that
he shall go.

sp.speaker: Fal.
Prin.
sp.p:
Farewell the latter Spring. Farewell Alhollown
Summer.

sp.speaker: Poy.
sp.p:
Now, my good sweet Honey Lord, ride with us
tomorrow. I have a jest to execute, that I cannot manage alone. Falstaffe, Haruey, Rossill, and Gads-hill, shall
rob those men that we have already way-laid,
yourself and I, will not be there: and when they have the booty, if you and I do not rob them, cut this head from my
shoulders.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But how shall we part with them in setting forth?

sp.speaker: Poyn.
sp.p:
Why, we will set forth before or after them, and
appoint them a place of meeting, wherein it is at our pleasure to fail; and then will they adventure upon the exploit themselves, which they shall have no sooner achieved, but we will set upon them.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Aye, but it is like that they will know us by our
horses, by our habits, and by every other appointment to
be ourselves.

sp.speaker: Poy.
sp.p:
Tut our horses they shall not see, I will tie them in
the wood, our vizards we will change after we leave
them: and sirrah, I have Cases of Buckram for the nonce,
to enmask our noted outward garments.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: But I doubt they will be too hard for us.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p:
Well, for two of them, I know them to be as
true bred Cowards as ever turned back: and for the third
if he fight longer than he sees reason, I will forswear Arms.
The virtue of this Jest will be, the incomprehensible lies
that this fat Rogue will tell us, when we meet at Supper:
how thirty at least he fought with, what Wards, what
blows, what extremities he endured; and in the reproof
of this, lies the jest.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Well, I will go with thee, provide us all things
necessary, and meet me tomorrow night in Eastcheape,
there I will sup. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Poyn.
sp.p: Farewell, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I know you all, and will awhile uphold
The unyoked humour of your idleness:
Yet herein will I imitate the Sun,
Who doth permit the base contagious clouds
To smother up his Beauty from the world,
That when he please again to be himself,
Being wanted, he may be more wondered at,
By breaking through the foul and ugly mists
Of vapours, that did seem to strangle him.
If all the year were playing holidays,
To sport, would be as tedious as to work;
But when they seldom come, they wished-for come,
And nothing pleaseth but rare accidents.
So when this loose behaviour I throw off,
And pay the debt I never promised;
By how much better than my word I am,
By so much shall I falsify men's hopes,
And like bright Metal on a sullen ground:
My reformation glittering over my fault,
Shall show more goodly, and attract more eyes,
Than that which hath no foil to set it off.
I will so offend, to make offence a skill,
Redeeming time, when men think least I will.

div2.head: Scoena Tertia.
div2.stage: Enter the King, Northumberland, Worcester, Hotspurre, Sir Walter Blunt, and others.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My blood hath been too cold and temperate,
Unapt to stir at these indignities,
And you have found me; for accordingly,
You tread upon my patience: But be sure,
I will from henceforth rather be myself,
Mighty, and to be feared, than my condition
Which hath been smooth as Oil, soft as young Down,
And therefore lost that Title of respect,
Which the proud soul never pays, but to the proud.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Our house (my Sovereign Liege) little deserves
The scourge of greatness to be used on it,
And that same greatness too, which our own hands
Have helped to make so portly.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Worcester get thee gone: for I do see
Danger and disobedience in thine eye.
O sir, your presence is too bold and peremptory,
And Majesty might never yet endure
The moody Frontier of a servant brow,
You have good leave to leave us. When we need
Your use and counsel, we shall send for you.
You were about to speak.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Yea, my good Lord.
Those Prisoners in your Highness demanded,
Which Harry Percy here at Holmedon took,
Were (as he says) not with such strength denied
As was delivered to your Majesty:
Who either through envy, or misprision,
Was guilty of this fault; and not my Son.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: My Liege, I did deny no Prisoners.
But, I remember when the fight was done,
When I was dry with Rage, and extreme Toil,
Breathless, and Faint, leaning upon my Sword,
Came there a certain Lord, neat and trimly dressed;
Fresh as a Bridegroom, and his Chin new reaped,
Showed like a stubble Land at Harvest home.
He was perfumed like a Milliner,
And betwixt his Finger and his Thumb, he held
A Pouncet-box: which ever and anon
He gave his Nose, and took it away again:
Who therewith angry, when it next came there,
Took it in Snuff. And still he smiled and talked:
And as the Soldiers bore dead bodies by,
He called them untaught Knaves, Unmannerly,
To bring a slovenly unhandsome Coarse
Betwixt the Wind, and his Nobility.
With many Holiday and Lady term
He questioned me: Among the rest, demanded
My Prisoners, in your Majesties behalf.
I then, all-smarting, with my wounds being cold,
(To be so pestered with a Popinjay)
Out of my Grief, and my Impatience,
Answered (neglectingly) I know not what,
He should, or should not: For he made me mad,
To see him shine so brisk, and smell so sweet,
And talk so like a Waiting-Gentlewoman,
Of Guns, & Drums, and Wounds: God save the mark;
And telling me, the Sovereignest thing on earth
Was Parmacity, for an inward bruise:
And that it was great pity, so it was,
That villainous Salt-peter should be digged
Out of the Bowels of the harmless Earth,
Which many a good Tall Fellow had destroyed
So Cowardly. And but for these vile Guns,
He would himself have been a Soldier.
This bald, unjointed Chat of his (my Lord)
Made me to answer indirectly (as I said.)
And I beseech you, let not this report
Come currant for an Accusation,
Betwixt my Love, and your high Majesty.

sp.speaker: Blunt.
sp.l: The circumstance considered, good my Lord,
What ever Harry Percie then had said,
To such a person, and in such a place,
At such a time, with all the rest retold,
May reasonably die, and never rise
To do him wrong, or any way impeach
What then he said, so he unsay it now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why yet doth deny his Prisoners,
But with Proviso and Exception,
That we at our own charge, shall ransom straight
His Brother-in-Law, the foolish Mortimer,
Who (in my soul) hath wilfully betrayed
The lives of those, that he did lead to Fight,
Against the great Magician, damned Glendower:
Whose daughter (as we hear) the Earl of March
Hath lately married. Shall our Coffers then,
Be emptied, to redeem a Traitor home?
Shall we buy Treason? and indent with Fears,
When they have lost and forfeited themselves.
No: on the barren Mountain let him starve:
For I shall never hold that man my Friend,
Whose tongue shall ask me for one penny cost
To ransom home revolted Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Revolted Mortimer?
He never did fall off, my Sovereign Liege,
But by the chance of War: to prove that true,
Needs no more but one tongue. For all those Wounds,
Those mouthed Wounds, which valiantly he took,
When on the gentle Seuernes sedgy bank,
In single Opposition hand to hand,
He did confound the best part of an hour
In changing hardiment with great Glendower:
Three times they breathed, and three times did they drink
Upon agreement, of swift Seuernes flood;
Who then affrighted with their bloody looks,
Ran fearefully among the trembling Reeds,
And hid his crisp-head in the hollow bank,
Blood-stained with these Valiant Combatants.
Never did base and rotten Policy
Colour her working with such deadly wounds;
Nor never could the Noble Mortimer
Receive so many, and all willingly:
Then let him not be slandered with Revolt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou dost belie him Percy, thou dost belie him;
He never did encounter with Glendower:
I tell thee, he durst as well have met the devil alone,
As Owen Glendower for an enemy.
Art thou not ashamed? But Sirrah, henceforth
Let me not hear you speak of Mortimer.
Send me your Prisoners with the speediest means,
Or you shall hear in such a kind from me
As will displease ye. My Lord Northumberland,
We License your departure with your son,
Send us your Prisoners, or you will hear of it.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: And if the devil come and roar for them
I will not send them. I will after straight
And tell him so: for I will ease my heart,
Although it be with hazard of my head.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: What? drunk with choler? stay & pause awhile,
Here comes your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Speak of Mortimer?
Yes, I will speak of him, and let my soul
Want mercy, if I do not join with him.
In his behalf, I will empty all these Veins,
And shed my dear blood drop by drop in the dust,
But I will lift the downfall Mortimer
As high in the Air, as this Unthankful King,
As this Ingrate and Cankered Bullingbrooke.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Brother, the King hath made your Nephew mad

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Who struck this heat up after I was gone?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: He will (forsooth) have all my Prisoners:
And when I urged the ransom once again
Of my Wives Brother, then his cheek looked pale,
And on my face he turned an eye of death,
Trembling even at the name of Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I cannot blame him: was he not proclaimed
By Richard that dead is, the next of blood?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: He was: I heard the Proclamation,
And then it was, when the unhappy King
(Whose wrongs in us God pardon) did set forth
Upon his Irish Expedition:
From whence he intercepted, did return
To be deposed, and shortly murthered.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: And for whose death, we in the worlds wide mouth
Live scandalised, and foully spoken of.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: But soft I pray you; did King Richard then
Proclaim my brother Mortimer,
Heir to the Crown?

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: He did, myself did hear it.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Nay then I cannot blame his Cousin King,
That wished him on the barren Mountains starved.
But shall it be, that you that set the Crown
Upon the head of this forgetful man,
And for his sake, wore the detested blot
Of murtherous subornation? Shall it be,
That you a world of curses undergo,
Being the Agents, or base second means,
The Cords, the Ladder, or the Hangman rather?
O pardon, if that I descend so low,
To show the Line, and the Predicament
Wherein you range under this subtle King.
Shall it for shame, be spoken in these days,
Or fill up Chronicles in time to come,
That men of your Nobility and Power,
Did gage them both in an unjust behalf
(As Both of you, God pardon it, have done)
To put down Richard, that sweet lovely Rose,
And plant this Thorne, this Canker Bullingbrooke?
And shall it in more shame be further spoken,
That you are fooled, discarded, and shook off
By him, for whom these shames ye underwent?
No: yet time serves, wherein you may redeem
Your banished Honours, and restore yourselves
Into the good Thoughts of the world again.
Revenge the gearing and disdained contempt
Of this proud King, who studies day and night
To answer all the Debt he owes unto you,
Even with the bloody Payment of your deaths:
Therefore I say---

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Peace Cousin, say no more.
And now I will unclasp a Secret book,
And to your quick conceiving Discontents,
I will read you Matter, deep and dangerous,
As full of peril and adventurous Spirit,
As to overwalk a Current, roaring loud
On the unsteadfast footing of a Spear.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: If he fall in, good night, or sink or swim:
Send danger from the East unto the West,
So Honour cross it from the North to South,
And let them grapple: The blood more stirs
To rouse a Lion, than to start a Hare.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Imagination of some great exploit,
Drives him beyond the bounds of Patience.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: By heaven, methinks it were an easy leap,
To pluck bright Honour from the pale-faced Moon,
Or dive into the bottom of the deep,
Where Fathom-line could never touch the ground,
And pluck up drowned Honour by the Locks:
So he that doth redeem her thence, might wear
Without Co-riual, all her Dignities:
But out upon this half faced Fellowship.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: He apprehends a World of Figures here,
But not the form of what he should attend:
Good Cousin give me audience for awhile,
And list to me.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Those same Noble Scots
That are your Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I will keep them all.
By heaven, he shall not have a Scot of them:
No, if a Scot would save his Soul, he shall not.
I will keep them, by this Hand.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: You start away,
And lend no ear unto my purposes.
Those Prisoners you shall keep.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Nay, I will; that is flat:
He said, he would not ransom Mortimer:
Forbade my tongue to speak of Mortimer.
But I will find him when he lies asleep,
And in his ear, I will holla Mortimer.
Nay, I will have a Starling shall be taught to speak
Nothing but Mortimer, and give it him,
To keep his anger still in motion.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Hear you Cousin: a word.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: All studies here I solemnly defy,
Save how to gall and pinch this Bullingbrooke,
And that same Sword and Buckler Prince of Wales.
But that I think his Father loves him not,
And would be glad he met with some mischance,
I would have poisoned him with a pot of Ale.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Farewell Kinsman: I will talk to you
When you are better tempered to attend.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Why what a Wasp-tongued & impatient fool
Art thou, to break into this Woman's mood,
Tying thine ear to no tongue but thine own?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Why look you, I am whipped & scourged with rods,
Nettled, and stung with Pismires, when I hear
Of this vile Politician Bullingbrooke.
In Richards time: What do ye call the place?
A plague upon it, it is in Gloustershire:
It was, where the madcap Duke his Uncle kept,
His Uncle Yorke, where I first bowed my knee
Unto this King of Smiles, this Bullingbrooke:
When you and he came back from Rauenspurgh.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: At Barkley Castle.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: You say true:
Why what a caudie deal of courtesy,
This fawning Grey-hound then did proffer me.
Look when his infant Fortune came to age,
And gentle Harry Percy, and kind Cousin:
O, the Devil take such Cozeners, God forgive me,
Good Uncle tell your tale, for I have done.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Nay, if you have not, to it again,
We will stay your leisure.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I have done insooth.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Then once more to your Scottish Prisoners.
Deliver them up without their ransom straight,
And make the Dowglas son your only mean
For powers in Scotland: which for divers reasons
Which I shall send you written, be assured
Will easily be granted you, my Lord.
Your Son in Scotland being thus implied,
Shall secretly into the bosom creep
Of that same noble Prelate, well beloved,
The Archbishop.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Of Yorke, is it not?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: True, who bears hard
His Brothers death at Bristow, the Lord Scroope.
I speak not this in estimation,
As what I think might be, but what I know
Is ruminated, plotted, and set down,
And only stays but to behold the face
Of that occasion that shall bring it on.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I smell it:
Upon my life, it will do wondrous well.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Before the game is afoot, thou still lettest slip.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Why, it cannot choose but be a Noble plot,
And then the power of Scotland, and of Yorke
To join with Mortimer, Ha.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: And so they shall.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: I'faith it is exceedingly well aimed.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: And it is no little reason bids us speed,
To save our heads, by raising of a Head:
For, bear ourselves as even as we can,
The King will always think him in our debt,
And think, we think ourselves unsatisfied,
Till he hath found a time to pay us home.
And see already, how he doth begin
To make us strangers to his looks of love.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: He does, he does; we will be revenged on him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Cousin, farewell. No further go in this,
Than I by Letters shall direct your course
When time is ripe, which will be suddenly:
I will steal to Glendower, and lo, Mortimer,
Where you, and Dowglas, and our powers at once,
As I will fashion it, shall happily meet,
To bear our fortunes in our own strong arms,
Which now we hold at much uncertainty.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.l: Farewell good Brother, we shall thrive, I trust.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Uncle, adieu: O let the hours be short,
Till fields, and blows, and groans, applaud our sport.

div2.head: Actus Secundus. Scena Prima.
div2.stage: Enter a Carrier with a Lanterne in his hand.

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.p:
Heigh-ho, if it be not four by the day, I will be
hanged. Charles wain is over the new Chimney, and yet
our horse not packed. What Ostler?

sp.speaker: Ost.
sp.p: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.p:
I prithee Tom, beat Cuts Saddle, put a few
Flocks in the point: the poor Jade is wrung in the withers, out of all cease.

sp.speaker: 2. Car.
sp.p:
Peas and Beans are as dank here as a Dog,
and this is the next way to give poor Jades the Bots:
This house is turned upside down since Robin the Ostler
died.

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.p:
Poor fellow never joyed since the price of oats
rose, it was the death of him.

sp.speaker: 2. Car.
sp.p:
I think this is the most villainous house in all
London road for Fleas: I am stung like a Tench.

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.p:
Like a Tench? There is never a King in Christendom, could be better bit, than I have been since the
first Cock.

sp.speaker: 2. Car.
sp.p:
Why, you will allow us never a Jordan, and
then we leak in your Chimney: and your Chamber-lie
breeds Fleas like a Loach.

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.p:
What Ostler, come away, and be hanged: come
away.

sp.speaker: 2. Car.
sp.p:
I have a Gammon of Bacon, and two razes of
Ginger, to be delivered as far as Charing-crosse.

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.p:
The Turkeys in my Pannier are quite starved.
What Ostler? A plague on thee, hast thou never an eye in
thy head? Canst not hear? If it were not as good a
deed as drink, to break the pate of thee, I am a very Villain. Come and be hanged, hast no faith in thee?

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Good-morrow Carriers. What is o'clock?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I think it be two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: I prithee lend me thy Lantern to see my Gelding in the stable.

sp.speaker: 1. Car.
sp.p:
Nay soft I pray ye, I know a trick worth two
of that.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: I prithee lend me thine.

sp.speaker: 2. Car.
sp.p:
Aye, when, canst tell? Lend me thy Lantern
(quoth he) marry I will see thee hanged first.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
Sirrah Carrier: What time do you mean to come
to London?

sp.speaker: 2. Car.
sp.p:
Time enough to go to bed with a Candle, I
warrant thee. Come neighbour Mugges, we will call up
the Gentlemen, they will along with company, for they
have great charge.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: What ho, Chamberlain?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p: At hand quoth Pick-purse.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
That is even as fair, as at hand quoth the Chamberlain: For thou variest no more from picking of Purses, than giving direction, doth from labouring. Thou
layest the plot, how.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Good morrow Master Gads-Hill, it holds currant that I told you yesternight. There is a Franklin in the
wild of Kent, hath brought three hundred Marks with
him in Gold: I heard him tell it to one of his company last
night at Supper; a kind of Auditor, one that hath abundance of charge too (God knows what) they are up already, and call for Eggs and Butter. They will away
presently.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
Sirrah, if they meet not with S. Nicholas Clarks,
I will give thee this neck.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
No, I will none of it: I prithee keep that for the
Hangman, for I know thou worshipest S. Nicholas as truly as a man of falsehood may.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
What talkest thou to me of the Hangman? If I
hang, I will make a fat pair of Gallows. For, if I hang,
old Sir Iohn hangs with me, and thou knowest he is no
Starveling. Tut, there are other Trojans that you dreamest
not of, the which (for sport sake) are content to do the
Profession some grace; that would (if matters should be
looked into) for their own Credit sake, make all Whole.
I am joined with no Foot-land-Rakers, no Long-staff
six-penny strikers, none of these mad Mustachio-purple-hued-Maltworms, but with Nobility, and Tranquillity;
Burgomasters, and great Ones, such as can hold in,
such as will strike sooner than speak; and speak sooner
than drink, and drink sooner than pray: and yet I lie,
for they pray continually unto their Saint the Commonwealth; or rather, not to pray to her, but prey on her: for
they ride up & down on her, and make her their Boots.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
What, the Commonwealth their Boots? Will
she hold out water in foul way?

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
She will, she will; Justice hath liquored her. We
steal as in a Castle, cocksure: we have the receipt of Fern-seed, we walk invisible.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Nay, I think rather, you are more beholding
to the Night, than to the Fern-seed, for your walking invisible.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
Give me thy hand.
Thou shalt have a share in our purpose,
As I am a true man.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.p:
Nay, rather let me have it, as you are a false
Thief.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
Go to: Homo is a common name to all men.
Bid the Ostler bring the Gelding out of the stable. Farewell, ye muddy Knave.

div2.head: Scaena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Poines.
sp.p:
Come shelter, shelter, I have removed Falstafs
Horse, and he frets like a gummed Velvet.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Stand close.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Poines, Poines, and be hanged Poines.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Peace ye fat-kidneyed Rascal, what a brawling
dost thou keep.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What Poines. Hal?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
He is walked up to the top of the hill, I will go seek
him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I am accursed to rob in that Thief company: that
Rascal hath removed my Horse, and tied him I know not
where. If I travel but four foot by the squire further a
foot, I shall break my wind. Well, I doubt not but
to die a fair death for all this, if I scape hanging for killing that Rogue, I have forsworn his company hourly
any time this two and twenty year, & yet I am bewitched
with the Rogues company. If the Rascal have not given
me medicines to make me love him, I will behanged; it could
not be else: I have drunk Medicines. Poines, Hal, a
Plague upon you both. Bardolph, Peto: I will starve ere I
rob a foot further. If it were not as good a deed as to
drink, to turn True-man, and to leave these Rogues, I
am the veriest Varlet that ever chewed with a Tooth.
Eight yards of uneven ground, is threescore & ten miles
afoot with me: and the stony-hearted Villains know it
well enough. A plague upon it, when Thieves cannot be
true one to another.
They Whistle. Whew: a plague light upon you all. Give my Horse you
Rogues: give me my Horse, and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Peace ye fat guts, lie down, lay thine ear
close to the ground, and list if thou can hear the tread of
Travellers.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Have you any Leavers to lift me up again being
down? I will not bear mine own flesh so far afoot again,
for all the coin in thy Fathers Exchequer. What a plague
mean ye to colt me thus?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Thou liest, thou art not colted, thou art uncolted.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I prithee good Prince Hal, help me to my horse,
good Kings son.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Out you Rogue, shall I be your Ostler?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Go hang thyself in thine own heir-apparent-Garters: If I be taken, I will peach for this: and I have not
Ballads made on all, and sung to filthy tunes, let a Cup of
Sack be my poison: when a jest is so forward, & a foot
too, I hate it.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Stand.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: So I do against my will.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: O it is our Setter, I know his voice:

sp.speaker: Bardolfe,
sp.p: what news?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Case ye, case ye; on with your Vizards, there is
money of the Kings coming down the hill, it is going
to the Kings Exchequer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You lie you rogue, it is going to the Kings Tavern.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: There is enough to make us all.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: To be hanged.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
You four shall front them in the narrow Lane:
Ned and I, will walk lower; if they scape from your encounter, then they light on us.

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.p: But how many be of them?

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: Some eight or ten.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Will they not rob us?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What, a Coward Sir Iohn Paunch?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Indeed I am not Iohn of Gaunt your Grandfather;
but yet no Coward, Hal.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: We will leave that to the proof.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p:
Sirrah Iacke, thy horse stands behind the hedge,
when thou needest him, there thou shalt find him. Farewell, and stand fast.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Now cannot I strike him, if I should be hanged.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Ned, where are our disguises?

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Here hard by: Stand close.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Now my Masters, happy man be his dole, say I:
every man to his business.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
Come Neighbour: the boy shall lead our Horses
down the hill: We will walk afoot a while, and ease our
Legs.

sp.speaker: Theeues.
sp.p: Stay.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Jesu bless us.

sp.speaker: Fal.
Tra.
sp.p: O, we are undone, both we and ours for ever.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang ye gor-bellied knaves, are you undone? No
ye Fat Chuffs, I would your store were here. On Bacons, on, what ye knaves? Young men must live, you are
Grand Jurors, are ye? We will jure ye i'faith.

div2.stage: Heere they rob them, and binde them. Enter the Prince and Poines.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
The Thieves have bound the True-men: Now
could thou and I rob the Thieves, and go merrily to London, it would be argument for a Week, Laughter for a
Month, and a good jest for ever.

sp.speaker: Poynes.
sp.p: Stand close, I hear them coming.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Come my Masters, let us share, and then to horse
before day: and the Prince and Poynes be not two arrant Cowards, there is no equity stirring. There is no more
valour in that Poynes, than in a wild Duck.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Your money.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Villains.

div2.stage: As they are sharing, the Prince and Poynes set vpon them. They all run away, leauing the booty behind them.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Got with much ease. Now merrily to Horse:
The Thieves are scattered, and possessed with fear so strongly, that they dare not meet each other: each takes his fellow for an Officer. Away good Ned, Falstaffe sweats to
death, and Lards the lean earth as he walks along: were it
not for laughing, I should pity him.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.l: How the Rogue roared.

div2.head: Scoena Tertia.
div2.stage: Enter Hotspurre solus, reading a Letter.

sp.p:
But for mine own part, my Lord, I could be well contented to
be there, in respect of the love I bear your house.
He could be contented: Why is he not then? in respect of
the love he bears our house. He shows in this, he loves
his own Barn better than he loves our house. Let me
see some more. The purpose you undertake is dangerous.
Why that is certain: It is dangerous to take a Cold, to
sleep, to drink: but I tell you (my Lord fool) out of
this Nettle, Danger; we pluck this Flower, Safety. The
purpose you undertake is dangerous, the Friends you have named uncertain, the Time itself unguarded, and your whole
Plot too light, for the counterpoise of so great an Opposition.
Say you so, say you so: I say unto you again, you are a
shallow cowardly Hind, and you Lie. What a lack-brain is this? I protest, our plot is as good a plot as ever
was laid; our Friend true and constant: A good Plot,
good Friends, and full of expectation: An excellent plot,
very good Friends. What a Frosty-spirited rogue is this?
Why, my Lord of Yorke commends the plot, and the
general course of the action. By this hand, if I were now
by this Rascal, I could brain him with his Ladies Fan.
Is there not my Father, my Uncle, and myself, Lord
Edmund Mortimer, my Lord of Yorke, and Owen Glendour?
Is there not besides, the Dowglas? Have I not all their letters, to meet me in Arms by the ninth of the next Month? and are they not some of them set forward already?
What a Pagan Rascal is this? An Infidel. Ha, you shall
see now in very sincerity of Fear and Cold heart, will he
to the King, and lay open all our proceedings. O, I could
divide myself, and go to buffets, for moving such a dish
of skimmed Milk with so honourable an Action. Hang him,
let him tell the King we are prepared. I will set forwards
tonight.
Enter his Lady. How now Kate, I must leave you within these two hours.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O my good Lord, why are you thus alone?
For what offence have I this fortnight been
A banished woman from my Harries bed?
Tell me (sweet Lord) what is it that takes from thee
Thy stomach, pleasure, and thy golden sleep?
Why dost thou bend thine eyes upon the earth?
Start so often when thou sittest alone?
Why hast thou lost the fresh blood in thy cheeks?
And given my Treasures and my rights of thee,
To thick-eyed musing, and cursed melancholy?
In my faint-slumbers, I by thee have watched,
And heard thee murmur tales of Iron Wars:
Speak terms of manage to thy bounding Steed,
Cry courage to the field. And thou hast talked
Of Sallies, and Retires; Trenches, Tents,
Of Palisadoes, Frontiers, Parapets,
Of Basilisks, of Canon, Culverin,
Of Prisoners ransom, and of Soldiers slain,
And all the current of a heady fight.
Thy spirit within thee hath been so at War,
And thus hath so bestirred thee in thy sleep,
That beds of sweat hath stood upon thy Brow,
Like bubbles in a late-disturbed Stream;
And in thy face strange motions have appeared,
Such as we see when men restrain their breath
On some great sudden haste. O what portents are these?
Some heavy business hath my Lord in hand,
And I must know it: else he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: What ho; Is Gilliams with the Packet gone?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He is my Lord, an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Hath Butler brought those horses from the Sheriff?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: One horse, my Lord, he brought even now.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: What Horse? A Roan, a crop ear, is it not.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: It is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: That Roan shall be my Throne. Well, I will
back him straight. Esperance, bid Butler lead him forth
into the Park.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But hear you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: What sayst thou my Lady?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What is it carries you away?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Why, my horse (my Love) my horse.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Out you mad-headed Ape, a Weasel hath not
such a deal of Spleen, as you are tossed with. In sooth I will
know your business Harry, that I will. I fear my Brother Mortimer doth stir about his Title, and hath sent
for you to line his enterprise. But if you go---

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: So far afoot, I shall be weary, Love.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Come, come, you Paraquito, answer me directly
unto this question, that I shall ask. Indeed I will break
thy little finger Harry, if thou wilt not tell me true.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Away, away you trifler: Love, I love thee not,
I care not for thee Kate: this is no world
To play with Mammets, and to tilt with lips.
We must have bloody Noses, and cracked Crowns,
And pass them currant too. Gods me, my horse.
What sayst thou Kate? what wouldst thou have with me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do ye not love me? Do ye not indeed?
Well, do not then. For since you love me not,
I will not love myself. Do you not love me?
Nay, tell me if thou speakest in jest, or no.

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Come, wilt thou see me ride?
And when I am a-horseback, I will swear
I love thee infinitely. But hark you Kate,
I must not have you henceforth, question me,
Whether I go: nor reason whereabout.
Whether I must, I must: and to conclude,
This Evening must I leave thee, gentle Kate.
I know you wise, but yet no further wise
Than Harry Percies wife. Constant you are,
But yet a woman: and for secrecy,
No Lady closer. For I will believe
Thou wilt not utter what thou dost not know,
And so far wilt I trust thee, gentle Kate.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How so far?

sp.speaker: Hot.
sp.l: Not an inch further. But hark you Kate,
Whither I go, thither shall you go too:
Today will I set forth, tomorrow you.
Will this content you Kate?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It must of force.

div2.head: Scena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Ned, prithee come out of that fat room, & lend
me thy hand to laugh a little.

sp.speaker: Poines.
sp.p: Where hast been Hall?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
With three or four Logger-heads, amongst 3.
or fourscore Hogsheads. I have sounded the very base
string of humility. Sirrah, I am sworn brother to a leash of
Drawers, and can call them by their names, as Tom, Dicke,
and Francis. They take it already upon their confidence,
that though I be but Prince of Wales, yet I am the King
of Courtesy: telling me flatly I am no proud Iack like Falstaffe, but a Corinthian, a lad of mettle, a good boy, and
when I am King of England, I shall command all the good
Lads in East-cheape. They call drinking deep, dying Scarlet; and when you breath in your watering, then
they cry hem, and bid you play it off. To conclude, I am
so good a proficient in one quarter of an hour, that I can
drink with any Tinker in his own Language during my
life. I tell thee Ned, thou hast lost much honour, that thou
were it not with me in this action: but sweet Ned, to sweeten which name of Ned, I give thee this pennyworth of Sugar, clapped even now into my hand by an under Skinker,
one that never spake other English in his life, than Eight
shillings and six pence, and, You are welcome: with this shrill
addition, Anon, Anon sir, Score a Pint of Bastard in the
Half Moon, or so. But Ned, to drive away time till Falstaffe come, I prithee do thou stand in some by-room,
while I question my puny Drawer, to what end he gave
me the Sugar, and do never leave calling Francis, that his
Tale to me may be nothing but, Anon: step aside, and I will
show thee a President.

sp.speaker: Poines.
sp.p: Francis.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Thou art perfect.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir; look down into the Pomgarnet, Ralfe.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Come hither Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How long hast thou to serve, Francis?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Forsooth five years, and as much as to---

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Five years: Byrlady a long Lease for the clinking of Pewter. But Francis, darest thou be so valiant, as
to play the coward with thy Indenture, & show it a fair
pair of heels, and run from it?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
O Lord sir, I will be sworn upon all the Books in
England, I could find in my heart.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How old art thou, Francis?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me see, about Michaelmas next I shalbe---

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon sir, pray you stay a little, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Nay but hark you Francis, for the Sugar thou
gavest me, it was a pennyworth, was it not?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O Lord sir, I would it had been two.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
I will give thee for it a thousand pound: Ask
me when thou wilt, and thou shalt have it.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Anon Francis? No Francis, but tomorrow Francis: or Francis, on thursday: or indeed Francis when thou
wilt. But Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Wilt thou rob this Leathern Jerkin, Crystal
button, Not-pated, Agate ring, Puke stocking, Caddis
garter, Smooth tongue, Spanish pouch.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O Lord sir, who do you mean?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Why then your brown Bastard is your only
drink: for look you Francis, your white Canvas doublet will sully. In Barbary sir, it cannot come to so much.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What sir?

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Francis.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Away you Rogue, dost thou hear them call?

div2.stage: Heere they both call him, the Drawer stands amazed, not knowing which way to go.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p:
What, standest thou still, and hearest such a calling? Look to the Guests within: My Lord, old Sir
Iohn with half a dozen more, are at the door: shall I let
them in?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Let them alone awhile, and then open the door.
Poines.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Sirrah, Falstaffe and the rest of the Thieves, are at
the door, shall we be merry?

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p:
As merry as Crickets my Lad. But hark ye,
What cunning match have you made this jest of the
Drawer? Come, what is the issue?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
I am now of all humours, that have showed themselves humours, since the old days of goodman Adam, to
the pupil age of this present twelve o'clock at midnight.
What is o'clocke Francis?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
That ever this Fellow should have fewer words
than a Parrot, and yet the son of a Woman. His industry is upstairs and down-stairs, his eloquence the parcel of a reckoning. I am not yet of Percies mind, the Hotspurre of the North, he that kills me some six or seven
dozen of Scots at a Breakfast, washes his hands, and says
to his wife; Fie upon this quiet life, I want work. O my
sweet Harry says she, how many hast thou killed today?
Give my Roan horse a drench (says he) and answers,
some fourteen, an hour after: a trifle, a trifle. I prithee
call in Falstaffe, I will play Percy, and that damned Brawn
shall play Dame Mortimer his wife. Riuo, says the drunkard. Call in Ribs, call in Tallow.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Welcome Iacke, where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
A plague of all Cowards I say, and a Vengeance
too, marry and Amen. Give me a cup of Sack Boy. Ere
I lead this life long, I will sow nether stocks, and mend
them too. A plague of all cowards. Give me a Cup of
Sack, Rogue. Is there no Virtue extant?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Didst thou never see Titan kiss a dish of Butter,
pitiful hearted Titan that melted at the sweet Tale of
the Sun? If thou didst, then behold that compound.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You Rogue, here is Lime in this Sack too: there
is nothing but Roguery to be found in Villainous man; yet
a Coward is worse than a Cup of Sack with lime. A villainous Coward, go thy ways old Iacke, die when thou
wilt, if manhood, good manhood be not forgot upon the
face of the earth, then am I a shotten Herring: there lives
not three good men unhanged in England, & one of them
is fat, and grows old, God help the while, a bad world I
say. I would I were a Weaver, I could sing all manner of
songs. A plague of all Cowards, I say still.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How now Wool sack, what matter you?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
A Kings Son? If I do not beat thee out of thy
Kingdom with a dagger of Lath, and drive all thy Subjects afore thee like a flock of Wild geese, I will never
wear hair on my face more. You Prince of Wales?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Why you whoreson round man? what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Are you not a Coward? Answer me to that, and
Poines there?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Ye fatch paunch, if ye call me Coward, I will
stab thee.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I call thee Coward? I will see thee damned ere I call
thee Coward: but I would give a thousand pound I could
run as fast as thou canst. You are straight enough in the
shoulders, you care not who sees your back: Call you
that backing of your friends? a plague upon such backing: give me them that will face me. Give me a Cup
of Sack, I am a Rogue if I drunk today.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
O Villain, thy Lips are scarce wiped, since
thou drunkest last.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
All is one for that.
He drinkes. A plague of all Cowards still, say I.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
What is the matter? here be four of us, have
taken a thousand pound this Morning.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Where is it, Iack? where is it?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Where is it? taken from us, it is: a hundred
upon poor four of us.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What, a hundred, man?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I am a Rogue, if I were not at half Sword with
a dozen of them two hours together. I have scaped by
miracle. I am eight times thrust through the Doublet,
four through the Hose, my Buckler cut through and
through, my Sword hacked like a Hand-saw, ecce signum.
I never dealt better since I was a man: all would not do.
A plague of all Cowards: let them speak; if they speak
more or less than truth, they are villains, and the sons
of darkness.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Speak sirs, how was it?

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: We four set upon some dozen.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Sixteen, at least, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p: And bound them.

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.p: No, no, they were not bound.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
You Rogue, they were bound, every man of
them, or I am a Jew else, an Ebrew Jew.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.p:
As we were sharing, some six or seven fresh men
set upon us.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
And unbound the rest, and then come in the
other.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What, fought ye with them all?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
All? I know not what ye call all: but if I
fought not with fifty of them, I am a bunch of Radish:
if there were not two or three and fifty upon poor old
Iack, then am I no two-legged Creature.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p:
Pray Heaven, you have not murthered some of
them.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Nay, that is past praying for, I have peppered
two of them: Two I am sure I have payed, two Rogues
in Buckram Suits. I tell thee what, Hal, if I tell thee a
Lie, spit in my face, call me Horse: thou knowest my old
word: here I lay, and thus I bore my point; four Rogues
in Buckram let drive at me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What, four? thou saidst but two, even now.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Four Hal, I told thee four.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, he said four.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
These four came all affront, and mainly thrust
at me; I made no more ado, but took all their seven
points in my Target, thus.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Seven? why there were but four, even now.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: In Buckram.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Aye, four, in Buckram Suits.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Seven, by these Hilts, or I am a Villain else.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Prithee let him alone, we shall have more anon.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Doest thou hear me, Hal?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Aye, and mark thee too, Iack.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Do so, for it is worth the listening too: these
nine in Buckram, that I told thee of.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: So, two more already.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Their Points being broken.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Down fell his Hose.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Began to give me ground: but I followed me
close, came in foot and hand; and with a thought, seven of
the eleven I paid.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
O monstrous! eleven Buckram men grown
out of two?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
But as the Devil would have it, three misbegotten Knaves, in Kendall Green, came at my Back, and
let drive at me; for it was so dark, Hal, that thou couldst
not see thy Hand.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
These Lies are like the Father that begets them,
gross as a Mountain, open, palpable. Why thou Clay-brained Guts, thou Knotty-pated Fool, thou Whoreson obscene greasy Tallow Catch.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
What, art thou mad? art thou mad? is not the
truth, the truth?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Why, how couldst thou know these men in
Kendall Green, when it was so dark, thou couldst not
see thy Hand? Come, tell us your reason: what sayst thou
to this?

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Come, your reason Iack, your reason.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
What, upon compulsion? No: were I at the
Strappado, or all the Racks in the World, I would not
tell you on compulsion. Give you a reason on compulsion? If Reasons were as plenty as Black-berries, I would
give no man a Reason upon compulsion, I.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
I will be no longer guilty of this sin. This sanguine Coward, this Bed-presser, this Horse-back-breaker,
this huge Hill of Flesh.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Away you Starveling, you Elf-skin, you dried
Neats tongue, Bull's pizzle, you stock fish: O for breath
to utter. What is like thee? You Tailors yard, you sheath
you Bow-case, you vile standing tuck.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Well, breath awhile, and then to it again: and
when thou hast tired thyself in base comparisons, hear
me speak but thus.

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: Mark Iacke.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
We two, saw you four set on four and bound
them, and were Masters of their Wealth: mark now how
a plain Tale shall put you down. Then did we two, set
on you four, and with a word, out-faced you from your
prize, and have it: yea, and can show it you in the House.
And Falstaffe, you carried your Guts away as nimbly, with
as quick dexterity, and roared for mercy, and still ran
and roared, as ever I heard bull calf. What a Slave art
thou, to hack thy sword as thou hast done, and then say
it was in fight. What trick? what device? what starting
hole canst thou now find out, to hide thee from this open
and apparent shame?

sp.speaker: Poines.
sp.p:
Come, let us hear Iacke: What trick hast
thou now?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I knew ye as well as he that made ye. Why hear
ye my Masters, was it for me to kill the Heir apparent?
Should I turn upon the true Prince? Why, thou knowest
I am as valiant as Hercules: but beware Instinct, the Lion
will not touch the true Prince: Instinct is a great matter.
I was a Coward on Instinct: I shall think the better of
myself, and thee, during my life: I, for a valiant Lion,
and thou for a true Prince. But Lads, I am glad you have
the Money. Hostess, clap to the doors: watch tonight,
pray tomorrow. Gallants, Lads, Boys, Hearts of Gold,
all the good Titles of Fellowship come to you. What,
shall we be merry? shall we have a Play extempore.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Content, and the argument shall be, thy running
away.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A, no more of that Hall, if thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: My Lord, the Prince?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
How now my Lady the Hostess, what sayst
thou to me?

sp.speaker: Hostesse.
sp.p:
Marry, my Lord, there is a Noble man of the
Court at door would speak with you: he says, he
comes from your Father.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Give him as much as will make him a Royal
man, and send him back again to my Mother.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: What manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Hostesse.
sp.p: An old man.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
What doth Gravity out of his Bed at Midnight?
Shall I give him his answer?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Prithee do Iacke.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I'faith, and I will send him packing.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Now Sirs: you fought fair; so did you
Peto, so did you Bardol: you are Lions too, you ran
away upon instinct: you will not touch the true Prince;
no, fie.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: I'faith, I ran when I saw others run.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Tell me now in earnest, how came Falstaffes
Sword so hacked?

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.p:
Why, he hacked it with his Dagger, and said, he
would swear truth out of England, but he would make
you believe it was done in fight, and persuaded us to do
the like.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
Yea, and to tickle our Noses with Spear-grass,
to make them bleed, and then to beslobber our garments
with it, and swear it was the blood of true men. I did
that I did not this seven years before, I blushed to hear
his monstrous devices.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
O Villain, thou stolest a Cup of Sack eighteen years ago, and wert taken with the manner, and
ever since thou hast blushed extempore: thou hadst fire
and sword on thy side, and yet thou rannest away; what
instinct hadst thou for it?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
My Lord, do you see these Meteors? do you
behold these Exhalations?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: I do

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: What think you they portend?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Hot Livers, and cold Purses.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Choler, my Lord, if rightly taken.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
No, if rightly taken, Halter.
Enter Falstaffe. Here comes lean Iacke, here comes bare-bone. How
now my sweet Creature of Bombast, how long is it ago,
Iacke, since thou sawest thine own Knee?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
My own Knee? When I was about thy years
(Hal) I was not an Eagles Talent in the Waste, I could
have crept into any Alderman's thumb-ring: a plague
of sighing and grief, it blows a man up like a Bladder.
There is villainous News abroad; here was Sir Iohn
Braby from your Father; you must go to the Court in
the Morning. The same mad fellow of the North, Percy;
and he of Wales, that gave Amamon the Bastinado,
and made Lucifer Cuckold, and swore the Devil his true
Liege-man upon the Cross of a Welsh-hook; what a
plague call you him?

sp.speaker: Poin.
sp.p: O, Glendower.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Owen, Owen; the same, and his Son in Law
Mortimer, and old Northumberland, and the sprightly
Scot of Scots, Dowglas, that runs a Horseback up a
Hill perpendicular.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
He that rides at high speed, and with a Pistol
kills a Sparrow flying.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: You have hit it.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: So did he never the Sparrow.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Well, that Rascal hath good mettle in him,
he will not run.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Why, what a Rascal art thou then, to praise him
so for running?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
A-horseback (ye Cuckoo) but afoot he will
not budge afoot.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Yes Iacke, upon instinct.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I grant ye, upon instinct: Well, he is there too,
and one Mordake, and a thousand blue-Caps more.
Worcester is stolen away by Night: thy Fathers Beard is
turned white with the News; you may buy Land now
as cheap as stinking Mackrel.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Then it is like, if there come a hot Sun, and this
civil buffeting hold, we shall buy Maiden-heads as
they buy Hobnails, by the Hundreds.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
By the Mass Lad, thou sayst true, it is like we
shall have good trading that way. But tell me Hal, art
not thou horrible afeared? thou being Heir apparent,
could the World pick thee out three such Enemies again, as that Fiend Dowglas, that Spirit Percy, and that
Devil Glendower? Art not thou horrible afraid? Doth
not thy blood thrill at it?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Not a whit: I lack some of thy instinct.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Well, thou wilt be horrible chid tomorrow,
when thou comest to thy Father: if thou do love me,
practise an answer.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Do thou stand for my Father, and examine me
upon the particulars of my Life.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Shall I? content: This Chair shall be my
State, this Dagger my Sceptre, and this Cushion my
Crown.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Thy State is taken for a joint-stool, thy Golden Sceptre for a Leaden Dagger, and thy precious rich
Crown, for a pitiful bald Crown.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Well, and the fire of Grace be not quite out of
thee, now shalt thou be moved. Give me a Cup of Sack
to make mine eyes look red, that it may be thought I
have wept, for I must speak in passion, and I will do it
in King Cambyses vain.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Well, here is my Leg.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: And here is my speech: stand aside Nobility.

sp.speaker: Hostesse.
sp.p: This is excellent sport, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Weep not, sweet Queen, for trickling tears
are vain.

sp.speaker: Hostesse.
sp.p: O the Father, how he holds his countenance?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
For Gods sake Lords, convey my trustful Queen,
For tears do stop the floodgates of her eyes.

sp.speaker: Hostesse.
sp.p:
O rare, he doth it as like one of these harlotry
Players, as ever I see.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: Peace good Pint-pot, peace good Tickle-brain.
sp.p:
Harry, I do not only marvel where thou spendest thy
time; but also, how thou art accompanied: For though
the Chamomile, the more it is trodden, the faster it grows;
yet Youth, the more it is wasted, the sooner it wears.
Thou art my Son: I have partly thy Mothers Word,
partly my Opinion; but chiefly, a villainous trick of
thine Eye, and a foolish hanging of thy nether Lip, that
doth warrant me. If then thou be Son to me, here
lieth the point: why, being Son to me, art thou so
pointed at? Shall the blessed Son of Heaven prove a
Micher, and eat Black-berries? a question not to be
asked. Shall the Son of England prove a Thief, and
take Purses? a question to be asked. There is a thing,
Harry, which thou hast often heard of, and it is known to
many in our Land, by the Name of Pitch: this Pitch (as
ancient Writers do report) doth defile; so doth the company thou keepest: for Harry, now I do not speak to
thee in Drink, but in Tears; not in Pleasure, but in Passion; not in Words only, but in Woes also: and yet
there is a virtuous man, whom I have often noted in thy
company, but I know not his Name.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What manner of man, if it like your Majesty?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
A goodly portly man i'faith, and a corpulent,
of a cheerful Look, a pleasing Eye, and a most noble
Carriage, and as I think, his age some fifty, or (byrlady)
inclining to threescore; and now I remember me, his
Name is Falstaffe: if that man should be lewdly given,
he deceives me; for Harry, I see Virtue in his Looks.
If then the Tree may be known by the Fruit, as the Fruit
by the Tree, then peremptorily I speak it, there is Virtue
in that Falstaffe: him keep with, the rest banish. And
tell me now, thou naughty Varlet, tell me, where hast
thou been this month?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Dost thou speak like a King? do thou stand
for me, and I will play my Father.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Depose me: if thou dost it half so gravely, so
majestically, both in word and matter, hang me up by the
heels for a Rabbit-sucker, or a Poulters Hare.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Well, here I am set.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: And here I stand: judge my Masters.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Now Harry, whence come you?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: My Noble Lord, from East-cheape.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: The complaints I hear of thee, are grievous.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I'faith, my Lord, they are false: Nay, I will tickle
ye for a young Prince.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Swearest thou, ungracious Boy? henceforth
never look on me: thou art violently carried away from
Grace: there is a Devil haunts thee, in the likeness of a
fat old Man; a Tun of Man is thy Companion: Why
dost thou converse with that Trunk of Humours, that
Boulting-Hutch of Beastliness, that swollen Parcel of
Dropsies, that huge Bombard of Sack, that stuffed Cloak-bag of Guts, that roasted Manning Tree Ox with the
Pudding in his Belly, that reverend Vice, that grey Iniquity, that Father Ruffian, that Vanity in years? wherein is he good, but to taste Sack, and drink it? wherein
neat and cleanly, but to carve a Capon, and eat it? wherein Cunning, but in Craft? wherein Crafty, but in Villainy? wherein Villainous, but in all things? wherein worthy, but in nothing?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I would your Grace would take me with you:
whom means your Grace?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
That villainous abominable misleader of
Youth, Falstaffe, that old white-bearded Satan.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: My Lord, the man I know.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I know thou dost.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
But to say, I know more harm in him than in
myself, were to say more than I know. That he is old
(the more the pity) his white hairs do witness it:
but that he is (saving your reverence) a Whore-master, that I utterly deny. If Sack and Sugar be a fault,
Heaven help the Wicked: if to be old and merry, be a
sin, then many an old Host that I know, is damned:
if to be fat, be to be hated, then Pharaohs lean Kine are
to be loved. No, my good Lord, banish Peto, banish
Bardolph, banish Poines: but for sweet Iacke Falstaffe,
kind Iacke Falstaffe, true Iacke Falstaffe, valiant Iacke Falstaffe, and therefore more valiant, being as he is old Iack
Falstaffe, banish not him thy Harryes company, banish
not him thy Harryes company; banish plump Iacke, and
banish all the World.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I do, I will.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
O, my Lord, my Lord, the Sheriff, with a most
most monstrous Watch, is at the door.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Out you Rogue, play out the Play: I have much
to say in the behalf of that Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Hostesse.
sp.p: O, my Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Heigh, heigh, the Devil rides upon a Fiddlestick: what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Hostesse.
sp.p:
The Sheriff and all the Watch are at the
door: they are come to search the House, shall I let
them in?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Dost thou hear Hal, never call a true piece of
Gold a Counterfeit: thou art essentially made, without
seeming so.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: And thou a natural Coward, without instinct.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I deny your Mayor: if you will deny the
Sheriff, so: if not, let him enter. If I become not a Cart
as well as another man, a plague on my bringing up: I
hope I shall as soon be strangled with a Halter, as another.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Go hide thee behind the Arras, the rest
walk up above. Now my Masters, for a true Face and
good Conscience.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Both which I have had: but their date is out,
and therefore I will hide me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Call in the Sheriff.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Now Master Sheriff, what is your will with
me?

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: First pardon me, my Lord. A Hue and Cry hath
followed certain men unto this house.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What men?

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: One of them is well known, my gracious Lord,
a gross fat man.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: As fat as Butter.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: The man, I do assure you, is not here,
For I myself at this time have employed him:
And Sheriff, I will engage my word to thee,
That I will by tomorrow Dinner time,
Send him to answer thee, or any man,
For anything he shall be charged withal:
And so let me entreat you, leave the house.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: I will, my Lord: there are two Gentlemen
Have in this Robbery lost three hundred Marks.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: It may be so: if he have robbed these men,
He shall be answerable: and so farewell.

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: Good Night, my Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: I think it is good Morrow, is it not?

sp.speaker: She.
sp.l: Indeed, my Lord, I think it be two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: This oily Rascal is known as well as Poules:
go call him forth.

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.l: Falstaffe? fast asleep behind the Arras, and
snorting like a Horse.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Hark, how hard he fetches breath: search his
Pockets.

div2.stage: He searcheth his Pockets, and findeth certaine Papers.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: What hast thou found?

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.l: Nothing but Papers, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Let us see, what be they? read them.

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.l: Item, a Capon. ii.s.ii.d.
Item, Sauce iiii.d.
Item, Sack, two Gallons. v.s.viii.d.
Item, Anchovies and Sack after Supper. ii.s.vi.d.
Item, Bread. ob.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
O monstrous, but one half penny-worth of
Bread to this intolerable deal of Sack? What there is
else, keep close, we will read it at more advantage: there
let him sleep till day. I will to the Court in the Morning:
We must all to the Wars, and thy place shall be honourable. I will procure this fat Rogue a Charge of Foot,
and I know his death will be a Match of Twelve-score.
The Money shall be paid back again with advantage.
Be with me betimes in the Morning: and so good morrow Peto.

sp.speaker: Peto.
sp.p: Good morrow, good my Lord.

div2.head: Actus Tertius. Scena Prima.
div2.stage: Enter Hotspurre, Worcester, Lord Mortimer, Owen Glendower.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: These promises are fair, the parties sure,
And our induction full of prosperous hope.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: Lord Mortimer, and Cousin Glendower,
Will you sit down?
And Uncle Worcester; a plague upon it,
I have forgot the Map.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: No, here it is:
Sit Cousin Percy, sit good Cousin Hotspurre:
For by that Name, as oft as Lancaster doth speak of you,
His Cheeks look pale, and with a rising sigh,
He wisheth you in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: And you in Hell, as oft as he hears Owen Glendower spoke of.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: I cannot blame him: At my Nativity,
The front of Heaven was full of fiery shapes,
Of burning Cressets: and at my Birth,
The frame and foundation of the Earth
Shaked like a Coward.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: Why so it would have done at the same season,
if your Mothers Cat had but kittened, though yourself
had never been born.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: I say the Earth did shake when I was born.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: And I say the Earth was not of my mind,
If you suppose, as fearing you, it shook.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: The Heavens were all on fire, the Earth did
tremble.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: O, then the Earth shook
To see the Heavens on fire,
And not in fear of your Nativity.
Diseased Nature oftentimes breaks forth
In strange eruptions; and the teeming Earth
Is with a kind of Colic pinched and vexed,
By the imprisoning of unruly Wind
Within her Womb: which for enlargement striving,
Shakes the old Beldam Earth, and tumbles down
Steeples, and moss-grown Towers. At your Birth,
Our Grandam Earth, having this distemperature,
In passion shook.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: Cousin: of many men
I do not bear these Crossings: Give me leave
To tell you once again, that at my Birth
The front of Heaven was full of fiery shapes,
The Goats ran from the Mountains, and the Herds
Were strangely clamorous to the frighted fields:
These signs have marked me extraordinary,
And all the courses of my Life do show,
I am not in the Roll of common men.
Where is the Living, clipped in with the Sea,
That chides the Banks of England, Scotland, and Wales,
Which calls me Pupil, or hath read to me?
And bring him out, that is but Woman's Son,
Can trace me in the tedious ways of Art,
And hold me pace in deep experiments.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: I think there is no man speaks better Welsh:
I will to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Peace cousin Percy, you will make him mad.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: I can call Spirits from the vasty Deep.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: Why so can I, or so can any man:
But will they come, when you do call for them?

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: Why, I can teach thee, Cousin, to command the
Devil.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: And I can teach thee, Cousin, to shame the Devil,
By telling truth. Tell truth, and shame the Devil.
If thou have power to raise him, bring him hither,
And I will be sworn, I have power to shame him hence.
O, while you live, tell truth, and shame the Devil.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Come, come, no more of this unprofitable
Chat.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: Three times hath Henry Bullingbrooke made head
Against my Power: thrice from the Banks of Wye,
And sandy-bottomed Severn, have I hent him
Bootless home, and Weather-beaten back.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: Home without Boots,
And in foul Weather too,
How scapes he Agues in the Devils name?

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: Come, here is the Map:
Shall we divide our Right,
According to our three-fold order taken?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: The Arch-Deacon hath divided it
Into three Limits, very equally:
England, from Trent, and Severn. hitherto,
By South and East, is to my part assigned:
All Westward, Wales, beyond the Severn shore,
And all the fertile Land within that bound,
To Owen Glendower: And dear Cuz, to you
The remnant Northward, lying off from Trent.
And our Indentures Tripartite are drawn:
Which being sealed interchangeably,
(A Business that this Night may execute)
Tomorrow, Cousin Percy, you and I,
And my good Lord of Worcester, will set forth,
To meet your Father, and the Scottish Power,
As is appointed us at Shrewsbury.
My Father Glendower is not ready yet,
Nor shall we need his help these fourteen days:
Within that space, you may have drawn together
Your Tenants, Friends, and neighbouring Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: A shorter time shall send me to you, Lords:
And in my Conduct shall your Ladies come,
From whom you now must steal, and take no leave,
For there will be a World of Water shed,
Upon the parting of your Wives and you.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: Methinks my Moiety, North from Burton here,
In quantity equals not one of yours:
See, how this River comes me cranking in,
And cuts me from the best of all my Land,
A huge half Moon, a monstrous Candle out.
I will have the Currant in this place damned up,
And here the smug and Silver Trent shall run,
In a new Channel, fair and evenly:
It shall not wind with such a deep indent,
To rob me of so rich a Bottom here.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: Not wind? it shall, it must, you see it doth.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Yea, but mark how he bears his course,
And runs me up, with like advantage on the other side,
Gelding the opposed Continent as much,
As on the other side it takes from you.

sp.speaker: Worc.
sp.l: Yea, but a little Charge will trench him here,
And on this North side win this Cape of Land,
And then he runs straight and even.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: I will have it so, a little Charge will do it.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: I will not have it altered.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: Will not you?

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: No, nor you shall not.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: Who shall say me nay?

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: Why, that will I.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: Let me not understand you then, speak it in
Welsh.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: I can speak English, Lord, as well as you:
For I was trained up in the English Court;
Where, being but young, I framed to the Harp
Many an English Ditty, lovely well,
And gave the Tongue a helpful Ornament;
A Virtue that was never seen in you.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: Marry, and I am glad of it with all my heart,
I had rather be a Kitten, and cry mew,
Than one of these same Meeter Ballad-mongers:
I had rather hear a Brazen Candlestick turned,
Or a dry Wheel grate on the Axle-tree,
And that would set my teeth nothing an edge,
Nothing so much, as mincing Poetry;
It is like the forced gate of a shuffling Nag.

sp.speaker: Glend.
sp.l: Come, you shall have Trent turned.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.l: I do not care: I will give thrice so much Land
To any well-deserving friend;
But in the way of Bargain, mark ye me,
I will cavil on the ninth part of a hair.
Are the Indentures drawn? shall we be gone?

sp.speaker: Glend.
